head.title: Metro Briefing | New York: Harm From Acid Rain Persists

hedline.hl1: Metro Briefing | New York: Harm From Acid Rain Persists

body.head.byline: By Hope Reeves (NYT) (Compiled by Yilu Zhao)

abstract.p: Northeast Natural History Conference shares result of study that shows acid rain is still harming aquatic life in Adirondack streams, killing fish (S)

block.p: Acid rain continues to harm aquatic life in Adirondack streams, according to a study presented last week at the Northeast Natural History Conference. The study concluded that 19 of 22 streams in the western part of Adirondack Park surpassed the acidity threshold for wildlife and that 16 contained toxic levels of aluminum, which can kill fish. The researcher, Gregory Lawrence of the United States Geological Survey, said dangerous levels of aluminum have been detected in the streams for 15 years or more.
